content.description:
Pitch 1 5.8 80'- Follow a left angling crack/ramp to a corner where the crack starts to head straight up. Set up a gear belay here. (Lots of gear options for anchor but I recommend saving finger size stuff .4-.75)  

  Pitch 2 5.10a 110'- Ahhh the good stuff. Head straight up to a short OW section to a roof. Go left out of the roof and follow a crack to the summit.  

  Rap: There is a two bolt anchor on top. Rap 95' (single 60m) down to the east saddle and hike back around the spire to packs.
content.protection: Double rack from .4-#4bd (#5 camelot optional) and nuts
content.location: North/East Face of Devil's Thumb    Park at Mystic Trailhead. Follow mystic 5-10 minutes and take a right on Hog Wash trail. Follow hog wash a couple minutes until you are looking up at Devils Thumb. Pick a line up to the thumb through washes and ridges. 20-30min approach.   Protection

content.description: Interesting old school route worth doing for those who are into chimneys.   P1. Nice hand crack(crux) with an old rope slung around a boulder dangling over it to a dirty ledge.Left and into the deep chimney to a dirty ledge.   P2. Right up the short easy off with/face to the top.
content.protection: Small to large cams. Off width gear not necessary. Bolt anchor on top. Single 70 m rap
content.location: Obvious thumb shaped short spire up and left of the Planetarium. Park at the Mystic trailhead as for the Planetarium. Once on the trail instead of following the climber's path to planetarium keep going until reaching a drainage on the right with a 2 pipe bridge under the trail and some cairns in the drainage. Follow it as far as you can up towards the limestone band, after scrambling up a section of slickrock brake left and up faint path over taulus to a brake in the limestone band. Scramble through, traverse slope until under the feature, scramble again to a notch right of the feature you will now see the dangling rope.

content.description:
This is the red thumb sticking off the west side of Twin Buttes. Highly visible from many parts of Sedona, especially Hwy-179.

 Currently there are two routes on this formation: 1. Southeast Chimney aka The Bearded Clam (5.7, 100 feet) is the original route. Short hand crack into a runout chimney with loose blocks up top. 2. Hangnail (5.10-, 190 feet) ascends a varied corner system on the northeast face. It's all about the second-pitch: a splitter 4" offwidth through a small roof.

 In May 2019, members of the first ascent party Tim Taber and Scott Sellers said that they named the spire the Praying Monk. The name most people use, however, is Devil's Thumb.

 Alternate names include:  - Elephant Rock  - Lost Chapel Spire
